Some of my Scandinavian friends explanied to me that in Viking times if a baby was born deformed or defective it went straight into the sea. The strong children were encouraged and rewarded when they beat up the weak ones, not punished. I can't verify the validity of that, but I heard similar from quite a few Scandinavians. In Denmark I definitely witnessed this type of mentality. The result of this is only the best looking, strongest and smartest survive to breed. Tribal selective breeding.

It's similar to stories I've heard about South American natives. One I heard is that when the women gave birth first a hole would be dug. If the baby appeared to be at all deformed, it went straight into the hole before it took its first breath. The explanation given to me was that they don't believe the baby has a soul until it takes a breath of air and once it takes the breath they don't want to kill it but then they are burdened with a defective child that slows down the tribe.

I believe that in ancient times it probably was perceived to be more cruel to allow a weaker less attractive life to live to maturity. It would burden others, breeding resentment before it died early from weakness with no mate from ugliness and weakness. It's nature, right
